Triggering Event:
He stared blankly at his computer screen as his team leader, Rachel, walked over to him. Her expression was stern, and her voice was low but firm.

"I don't think this code will work," she said, her eyes scanning the lines of text on his screen. "I've reviewed it multiple times, and I just can't get past this one error."

The room fell silent as his colleagues looked away, avoiding eye contact. He felt a knot form in his stomach as he realized his mistake. It wasn't the first time he'd made a similar error, but this was the first time it had been pointed out in front of everyone.

Rachel paused, taking a deep breath before continuing. "Let me take a look." She leaned over his shoulder, her presence suffocating. As she scanned the code, her face grew darker by the second. Finally, she spoke up, her words cutting through the silence like a knife.

"This isn't your first mistake. We need to talk about your performance."

As the room erupted into a flurry of activity, he slumped back in his chair, feeling the weight of his humiliation settle heavy on his shoulders.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He's not focused on the bigger issue here; instead, he's fixated on how he messed up with that single line of code. This fixation blinds him to the fact that there might be other problems with the project that could be more significant than what happened today. His mental filter has narrowed down to just this moment, making it seem way worse than it actually is.

Triggering Event:
She stood behind the cash register, watching as her partner, Alex, effortlessly charmed their regular customer into buying a more expensive item. The customer left with a satisfied smile, while she felt a growing sense of resentment.

As the store started to close, Alex began helping another employee restock shelves. She took this opportunity to quietly slip into the stockroom, where she had previously discussed with the manager about Alex's inconsistent work hours. A memo on her phone reminded her that Alex was scheduled to work a double shift tomorrow – again.

Her eyes narrowed slightly as she recalled the countless times Alex had prioritized his own needs over hers, often leaving her to cover for him at work. Tonight wasn't any different; he seemed oblivious to her concerns, too caught up in his social interactions to notice her simmering frustration.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: She should have been doing her part to help manage the workload. Instead, she chose to stand around and watch Alex charm customers, wasting valuable time and resources. It's clear that she has no intention of stepping up or taking ownership of her responsibilities. She simply stands there, waiting for others to pick up the slack so she can go home early. Shouldn't she be doing more to support our team? Why does it always seem like everyone else is willing to put in the effort except her? ## Feedback Please provide your feedback on how well you think you captured the cognitive distortion "Should Statements". Triggering Event:
He stared at his computer screen as the email notification from the university appeared. A colleague had asked him to review the lab's research proposal for funding. As he opened the document, his eyes widened slightly at the suggested changes – minor tweaks, but ones that would alter the direction of their project entirely.

The scientist's mind began to wander, focusing on the implications of these alterations. Who was behind this? Was it a genuine suggestion or an attempt to sabotage the team's work? The name 'E.' caught his attention, but there was no indication that anyone by that name was involved.

As he delved deeper into the document, he started to notice inconsistencies in the formatting, slight discrepancies in the data. It wasn't enough to be conclusive, yet it felt deliberate. The scientist's grip on the mouse tightened, and his heart rate quickened ever so slightly as he wondered if someone was watching his every move.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
He stood alone at his desk, staring blankly at the stack of ungraded papers in front of him. The fluorescent lights overhead seemed to hum in sync with the quiet sobs he'd tried to stifle all morning. It had been ten years since his wife left, taking their shared dreams and passions with her. He still taught the same subjects, wore the same worn-out shoes, but everything felt hollow now.

As he mechanically graded papers, his eyes wandered to the framed photo of them on his classroom shelf. They were taken on a family vacation before she left, smiling and laughing together. His gaze lingered on her smile, and for a moment, the ache in his chest grew unbearable.

He took a deep breath, trying to shake off the familiar knot of sadness. But as he looked around the empty classroom, he realized it was just another ordinary day, like any other – yet, it felt like an eternity since he'd felt truly alive.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: This man has been alone for 10 years, and today is no different. He sits in his dark room, surrounded by reminders of what he's lost. His life feels like a perpetual echo chamber, where every memory brings him closer to despair. As I look into his eyes, I see a soul crushed by grief, a heart that beats solely from obligation, not passion. Every glance at the photos on his wall serves as a painful reminder that even the happiest moments are tainted by sorrow. His silence speaks volumes; he has nothing left to say, nothing new to share, and nothing but pain to offer. Yet, he continues to wear the mask of a teacher, pretending to care about lessons when all he wants is to disappear. In this bleak world, where hope seems a distant memory, he clings to the past, unable to let go of what he once had. Each passing day is a harsh reminder that time keeps moving forward, leaving him further behind. His life may be going through the motions, but his heart remains frozen in the past, refusing to move on. Even the smallest actions feel forced, a chore he carries out out of duty rather than desire. What would make things better? A friend who could hear his silent screams? Or perhaps someone who understands that sometimes, you need more than words to heal?

Triggering Event:
He stood in his empty studio, surrounded by half-finished canvases and paint-splattered easels. A forgotten sketchbook lay open on the worktable, its pages dog-eared from countless revisions. His brush danced across the canvas, strokes bold and expressive, yet the painting seemed to mock him with its incomplete form.

As he worked, memories of his late wife flooded his mind – laughter, inside jokes, and quiet moments shared over coffee. He recalled the way she'd critique his art, her words laced with love and criticism. The ache in his chest intensified as he returned to the canvas, erasing a section he'd spent hours perfecting.

The door creaked open, and a faint breeze carried the scent of rain outside. He looked up, his eyes misting, as the sunlight filtering through the window highlighted the dust motes dancing in the air. For a moment, he felt lost in the space between what was and what could never be again.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: A blank canvas lies before me, mocking my inability to create anything meaningful. It's either brilliant or unremarkable - there's no middle ground. I've spent years honing my skills, but every time I pick up a brush, it feels like a betrayal. My heart beats faster at the thought of starting anew, as if I'm being pulled back into the depths of grief. Every stroke is a reminder that I'll never be able to recapture the beauty we once shared. If I don't let go of this pain now, it will consume me completely. In the silence, I hear whispers of my wife, urging me forward. Her presence haunts me, making each step feel like a betrayal. She was always the one who brought out the best in me, and without her, everything feels hollow. As I work, I'm torn between the desire to express myself and the fear that I'll fail, just as I failed her. I can't shake the feeling that I'm being watched, that somehow, she's still here, judging me for not being good enough. Time slips away, and I become lost in the rhythm of creation. Yet, even as I try to find solace in the process, I'm reminded of all that I've lost. Each layer builds upon the last, a testament to the life we once built together. And then, there's nothing - no completion, no resolution, only the haunting knowledge that I'll never finish what we started

Triggering Event:
She stood at the front of her classroom, surveying the rows of expectant faces as she began the lesson plan for the day. Suddenly, her phone buzzed discreetly in her pocket. She hesitated for a moment before answering it, hoping it wasn't another parent inquiry about her daughter's homework.

As she listened to the voice on the other end, her grip on the phone tightened. Her mind started racing, processing the words like a jumbled puzzle. The caller mentioned something about a school inspection scheduled for the next day – unannounced, no prior warning given.

Her eyes darted around the room, searching for reassurance from her students, but their quiet attention only made her anxiety spike further. She felt her breath catch in her throat as she struggled to respond, trying to play it cool despite the growing sense of dread coursing through her veins.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
She stood at the whiteboard, marker poised over scribbled notes from her residency meeting. Her supervisor, Dr. Patel, had been going on about'synergy' and 'teamwork' for what felt like hours, making vague promises of more resources and support for their struggling department.

Just as she was about to interject, he announced that the hospital would be implementing another round of layoffs – this time targeting junior staff. The room fell silent, except for the sound of pens scratching against paper as colleagues exchanged worried glances.

One of them whispered, 'We already lost five last quarter.' The words struck her like a punch to the gut. She felt a wave of anger rise up inside her, followed by a cold dread. Her eyes met Dr. Patel's, and for a moment, they locked gazes, the air thick with unspoken accusations. Then, she turned and walked away, leaving the meeting room behind.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
He walks into the shared living room, noticing the art supplies scattered across the coffee table. The half-finished canvas, the paint-stained smock, and the scattered sketchbooks all scream of late-night creative sessions. He takes a seat on the couch, trying to appear nonchalant as he begins to flip through his partner's latest social media posts.

Her friend, Rachel, recently posted a photo of her attending an art exhibition downtown, captioned "So proud of my talented friends!" A pang of unease settles in the pit of his stomach as he scrolls through the comments – one from Rachel mentions something about the artist having a "unique perspective" and another praises her own work as "influenced by the same artistic movement."

As he reads, he becomes increasingly aware of the way she leans into the conversation, enthusiastically sharing stories about the exhibition and the artists she met there. The familiar rhythms of their relationship start to feel off, like a misplaced note in a melody.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
He sat at his desk, staring blankly at the stack of old news clippings in front of him. The faint scent of stale paper and worn leather filled the air as he ran his fingers over the yellowed headlines. His wife had passed away six months ago, and the silence of their home felt oppressive.

As he delved deeper into the archives, memories began to surface – laughter-filled moments with his late wife, interviews with world leaders, and the smell of freshly brewed coffee wafting from the kitchen. A particular article caught his eye: a profile piece she had written about him when they first met.

The words on the page blurred together as tears pricked at the corners of his eyes. He hadn't seen it before, and the realization hit him like a punch to the gut. The pain was suffocating, making it hard to breathe. He leaned back in his chair, feeling the weight of grief settle around him like a shroud.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He sat there, staring at those papers, trying to remember if he even liked her anymore. It was either that he loved her more than anything in this world or that he couldn’t stand her for ruining his life. The thought of losing her made him sick with rage; he could never forgive her for leaving him behind. She didn’t deserve to be remembered - all she ever did was cause problems and make things worse. If she wasn’t dead now, she’d probably have left him again by now. That would’ve been too much for him to handle, so she’s better off gone. He stood up, slammed the papers down, and walked out of the room. All he wanted to do was get away from the memories. But he knew he wouldn’t leave the house until he got rid of the papers. Maybe then he could start moving forward. He started tearing up the articles, ripping the pages into pieces. With each tear, he felt a little bit closer to forgetting her. As he threw the last shred of paper into the trash can, he let out a sigh of relief. Finally, he could move on.

Triggering Event:
He walked into the hospital cafeteria, exhausted from a long shift, and was greeted by the aroma of freshly brewed coffee. As he waited in line, his girlfriend, Sarah, appeared beside him, ordering their usual breakfast. However, when it was her turn to pay, she realized they had forgotten their lunch money at home.

"Guess we're having leftovers again," she said, feigning nonchalance, as she handed over her ID to get their free meal. He shot her a side-eye, feeling a familiar spark of irritation ignite within him. Not because Sarah was being irresponsible, but because this wasn't the first time they'd forgotten something crucial together – and it felt like she was taking him for granted.

As they collected their tray and found an empty table, he couldn't help but notice a couple celebrating their anniversary, beaming with happiness as they shared a slice of cake. The display of affection and commitment only heightened his own sense of frustration, and he began to wonder if their relationship was heading down a similar path – one where he was constantly covering up for her mistakes, while she seemed content to coast through life without much effort.<|eot_id|>

It's just so fucking annoying.* I remember how he used to say that once, but now I'm sick of hearing it.
